resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
kou commented on pull request #6514: ARROW-7977: [C++] Rename fs::FileStats to fs::FileStat
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6514
 
 
   Because widely used stat(2) is an abbreviation of "status" not
   "statistics". It's better that we follow the widely used existing
   convention.
   
   Linux: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/stat.2.html
   
   > get file status
   
   https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=stat&sektion=2
   
   > get	file status
   
   If we use FileStat instead of FileStats, we can use singular form
   "stat" and plural form "stats" as variable names instead of "stats"
   and "stats_vector". It will help writing readable code.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

bkietz commented on issue #6514: ARROW-7977: [C++] Rename fs::FileStats to fs::FileStat
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6514#issuecomment-593619367
 
 
   @kou @pitrou @kszucs IMHO FileInfo is fine, but I prefer FileStat because "stat" pluralizes more naturally: stat->stats vs info->infos

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6514#issuecomment-593652186
 
 
   I'm also more in favor of `FileInfo`. I hate to bikeshed, but you could also call it `fs::PathInfo` (since it can apply to both files and directories).

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
If we use FileInfo instead of FileStats, we can use singular form
"info" and plural form "infos" as variable names instead of "stats"
and "stats_vector". It will help writing readable code.
